subject: Re: [junit] testing private methods

messageBody:
Manuel Amago wrote:

> The way I see the problem of testing private methods is:
> for those of you who would like to see this feature in JUnit, try
> developing a nice working solution that fits well into the existing
> JUnit codebase. I'm sure that, if well presented, the JUnit team would
> be willing to evaluate your solution and add it to a future release (is
> this true guys?).
>
> I believe that, if people want to test private methods (and this is an
> issue that crops up frequently), they should be allowed to do so (if
> such functionality is readilly available).

But as i pointed out way back when this began, JUnit can *already* test
private methods using existing features of Java access control. Just
code your JUnit test class as an inner class of the class being tested.
But some programmers object to this method, because it embeds the unit
tests in the code when they want the unit tests in a separate package
altogether. That's not a JUnit problem, that's a configuration
management problem, imho. The smell is in the tension between the
desired source code layout and the access rules of the language. I don't
see how JUnit is responsible for this smell, or a JUnit-based solution
(like, say, hacking it to use reflection in order to break access
control) that doesn't bring along serious code smells of its own.

I think we all agree that there's a smell here. We're just disagreeing
about how to handle the smell. I'll admit, using inner classes for unit
testing smells, too. I don't think it smells nearly as bad as breaking
access control, but that's just my opinion.

I rather liked JB Rainsberger's idea that the need to test a private
method directly suggests refactoring it into a collaborating class. I'm
not sure it's universally applicable, but i do prefer looking for smells
in my code rather than my tools.
